item.title: rss-patch.txt attached to Ticket #4595
item.dc:creator: terraces

item.title: Ticket #4595 (Format of feed (RSS, Atom) should be an option) created
item.dc:creator: terraces
item.description:
Summary

Currently, WordPress uses RSS 2.0 as the default format for its syndication feeds In case anyone wants a different default format, he must hack Wordpress core (or tell users to use /feed/type rather than /feed, but he still needs to change any page / template that links to the feeds). This patch allows users to choose default RSS type in the admin interface, in the Options / Reading page.

Version

This patch has been created from the current 2.3 SVN code (trunk).

Modified files

  • wp-includes/feed.php: Adds a wp_dropdown_feeds() method, that lists available feed types within <option> items to be used in a <select> list
  • wp-admin/options-reading.php: Displays the <select> list in the RSS options form to let user choose default type. Chosen type is saved as 'rss_format' in the wp_options table
  • wp-includes/functions.php: Use get_options('rss_format') rather than 'rss2' default for feed type

item.title: is_active_sidebar_api.diff attached to Ticket #4594
item.dc:creator: filosofo

item.title: Ticket #4594 (Widgets API to check for active sidebars) created
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
There should be a way to check if particular sidebar is in use, because a theme developer might want to change the markup in the presence of a sidebar actually being used.

My patch adds a "is_active_sidebar" function, to which one can pass a sidebar name, id, or number to return a boolean value reflecting whether that sidebar is actually in use.

item.title: Ticket #4593 (End tag of first <small> gets cut off post after save) created
item.dc:creator: BoltClock
item.description:
Tested in Firefox 2.0.0.4 and Opera 9.2, it seems that whenever I save a post, any number of closing tags for the first <small> element in the post gets removed.

I have to publish the post before WordPress stops cutting the ending tag off. Even after I convert the published post to a draft, the ending tag remains, as long as I have published the post at a point of time.

item.title: Ticket #4429 (add_option followed by update_option not always working) closed
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
fixed:

(In [5789]) Properly unset notoptions cache in add_option() so that get_option() and update_option() work on the same load. fixes #4429 for 2.2.x

item.title: Ticket #4591 (Go PHP5) closed
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
wontfix:

This has been brought up probably half a dozen times, and our position is the same.

  • PHP5 does not yet have sufficient penetration. On many hosts where it is available, it is not the default.
  • We're not going to turn WordPress into a protest piece at the expense of our users.
  • We're not going to set a date for the end of PHP4 support when there is no evidence to suggest that the hosting landscape will be any different on that date.

item.title: Ticket #4592 (You have all created some great software.) created
item.dc:creator: Bernard_J_L
item.description:
I just want to pass along to all of you who are working on WordPress that you have created some very impressive code. Just recently I did an upgrade and wanted to make a slight change to how the posts behaved. It was just incredible that your code so effortlessly found the new template and plug-in. I had to stop to just think about how your code did that.

From my experiences managing large programs I am further in awe that your team is able to have such well written code and internal structure. With such a broad base of supporters and users.

Keep up the great work.

Your software definitely has the WOW factor.

Thanks for all your efforts.
